A. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

General [40 CFR 68.155]

The regulation requires that an Executive Summary be provided as part of the registration submitted to the EPA. 

The following areas are addressed in this summary:

(a) The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source;
(b) The stationary source and regulated substances handled;
(c) The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps;
(d) The five-year accident history;
(e) The emergency response program; and,
(f)  Planned changes to improve safety.

(a) ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES AT THE STATIONARY SOURCE

Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) is committed to complying with all of the regulatory requirements of the EPA Risk Management Program. Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) has developed their Risk Management Plan / Process Safety Management (RMP/PSM) to document policies and address the implementation of these regulations. The PSM sections pertain to the prevention of accidental releases and include the Process Hazard Analysis study and procedures for operating, training, maintenance, emergency response, and others. The RMP sections pertain to management systems and include the Hazard Assessment (Offsite Consequence Analysis) Report.

Federal regulations require reporting when there is a release of ammonia exceeding 100 pounds in 24 hours.

State regulations require reporting when there is an accidental release of ammonia or a threat of accidental release of ammonia.  Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) interprets this regulation as any release that poses a threat of injury above and beyond minor irritation to anyone.

All releases and near misses are to be recorded using the incident investigation forms.  All releases are to be monitored and all readings recorded.  All releases and near misses are to be reviewed to develop procedu

res that may prevent future incidents.

Any release of more than 100 PPM may result in immediately shutting down the SCR ammonia system depending on the location of the release. The Duty Manager are to be called if not on site for support.  Releases less than 50 PPM shall result in immediately calling the Duty Manager, if not on site, for instructions.

The facility utilizes inspection procedures to review SCR process equipment on an ongoing basis.  These procedures identify potential sources of releases and equipment corrections required to prevent these releases. Onsite technicians, registered engineers, SCR process experts, and certified process contractors review the equipment as required.

There are full time managers and operational employees such as technicians at this facility that have been trained to conduct visual and audible inspections of the ammonia systems on a regular basis. They are instructed to report any condition that could result in an ammonia release immediately.  An example would be excessive rust on piping or tanks. This team activity is the core of Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) prevention program.  

 (b) STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
The Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) facility at 73396 Tower Road, Boardman, OR., utilizes anhydrous ammonia for NOx emission reduction. Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) is a gas in its natural state and is extremely irritating to mucous membranes and lung tissue. The gas is pungent and may displace oxygen. Prolonged inhalation of high concentrations may cause bronchitis and or pneumonia, with some residual reduction in pulmonary functions. Repeat or prolonged contact of high concentrations of ammonia to the skin can cause frostbite, redness, pain, serious skin burn, and even death.  Safety Data Sheet's (SDS) are provided for anhydrous ammonia in the appendix. The SDS provides information on; toxicity, permissible exposure limits, physical data, r

eactivity data, corrosively data, thermal and chemical stability data, and the hazardous effects of mixing with other materials.

The facility will operate year round with the exception of no more than 30 to 60 consecutive days of down time depending on demand.

(c) THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Key objectives of Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station)'s Prevention Program are briefly described below:

1) Maintain current and complete SCR process technical information. (Addressed under the Process Safety Information Element)

2) Provide thorough team evaluation of the SCR process.  The evaluation considers a number of potential problems including: mechanical problems, human errors, and external events (e.g., flooding, extreme weather, etc.).  All safety recommendations developed by the team are reviewed and addressed by Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) management.  (Addressed under Process Hazard Analysis and Maintenance Elements.

3) Written procedures and policies that establish how the SCR process should be operated and maintained and how to investigate accidental releases. (Addressed under Operating Procedures, Maintenance, and Incident Investigation Elements.) 

4) Certification of process operators (technicians) to safely operate the SCR process. Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) certifies technicians following completion of qualification training and Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station)'s confirmation of the technician's ability to apply what they have learned.  (Addressed under Training Element.)

5) Employee involvement in the Prevention Program.  This is addressed on two levels.  First, SCR process operators participate in the planning and evaluation of the Prevention Programs (e.g., Process Hazard Analysis study team, writing and/or reviewing operating procedures, Incident Investigation team, etc.).  This involvem

ent encourages ownership of the Prevention Program and positively affects the operators' day-to-day activities.  

Second, all Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) employees (direct hires and contract) at this facility receive ammonia awareness training.  Additionally, they have access to the RMP/PSM information.  These activities improve the overall safety of the employees. (Both levels are addressed under the Employee Participation and Training Elements)

6) Implementation of additional measures when changes are planned (procedural or mechanical).  These measures begin before any changes are made and may include a Process Hazard Analysis, operator training, and Process Safety Information updates plus other measures required by Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station)'s program.
 
If a mechanical change is required and for a change in maintenance contracts, Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) has a procedure for selecting a contractor based on the company's experience and safety history. Additionally, if welding, grinding, or other "Hot Work" occurs close to the ammonia system, a Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) Hot Work permit is required.  The purpose of the permit and the associated Hot Work procedure is to minimize the possibility of a fire. 

7) Verification of Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station)'s compliance with the RMP/PSM program.  This audit process is an important tool to confirm whether each of the elements in the program have been implemented and properly documented by Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) personnel.  Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) established a Management System procedure to address any shortcomings, which the audit may find. (Addressed under Compliance Audit Element)   

8) Minimize employee injury and illness. (Addressed under Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station)'s Safety and Health Program

.

PREVENTION PROGRAM 

Process Safety Information
Process Safety Information includes a wide variety of books, manuals, and process information. These are available to employees that operate, maintain, or repair the process equipment or piping. There are three major categories of information: ammonia data such as SDS, safety information, first aid, chemical properties, safety bulletins, etc.; process information such as piping & instrumentation diagrams (P&ID's), block flow diagram, design codes and standards, pressure safety relief settings, safety system/devices, operating procedures, safe operating limits, and ramification of process deviation; and process equipment information such as equipment specifications, materials of construction, installation manuals, operating and maintenance manuals, and manufacturer's manuals.

Process Hazard Analysis
A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was completed using the "What-if" checklist.  This addressed hazards, engineering and administrative controls, consequences of failure of engineering and administrative controls, facility siting, human factors, and a qualitative evaluation of the possible safety and health impact. The results of the PHA were prioritized and incorporated into a PHA Findings Report for follow-up as a corrective action log.


Operating Procedures and Technical Operating Specifications
The Technical Operating Specifications (TOS) made up of the process safety information and Standard Operating Procedures (SOP's) are provided for the process equipment.  Topics include general information such items as;

¿	Objectives 
¿	Special hazards 
¿	Location 
¿	Safety equipment needed 
¿	P&ID's  and Block Flow Diagrams
¿	Technical operating specifications, 
¿	Step-by-step procedures
¿	Specific warnings & PPE 

The SOPs cover different phases of operations such as: initial startup; normal, temporary and emergency operations; emergency shutdowns; and startup following a shutdown. Various other safety p

rograms and procedures are included.


Training 
All employees who are involved with anhydrous ammonia have been properly trained, at a minimum, in understanding the SDS, routine SCR process operation, emergency SCR process operation, emergency and normal safety practices, and the individual's role in the emergency response plan.

Mechanical Integrity and Maintenance
The purpose of the Maintenance and Mechanical Integrity program is to ensure that the equipment is maintained in good working condition.  Inspections, and ongoing maintenance based on industry standards or site history are performed on all process equipment including, pressure vessels, piping systems, relief/vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls, pumps etc.


Management of Change
The Management of Change (MOC) procedure requires that all changes (even "replacement in kind") be reviewed to see if there is a possible negative effect. The MOC review addresses the technical basis for the change, the impact on safety and health, modifications to operating procedures, and authorization requirements for the proposed change.  Employees affected by the change are informed of the change before startup and trained in the proper procedures.

Pre-Startup Review
Pre-startup safety reviews are required on all new or modified equipment/systems. This involves process safety information, process hazard analysis, training, safety procedures, operating procedures, and verification that construction and equipment are in accordance with the design specifications.

Compliance Audits
To insure that all the areas of the RMP/PSM program are followed, the company requires compliance audits.  At a minimum, these must be completed every three years.

Incident Investigation
An incident investigation shall be performed any time there is an incident which resulted in, or which could reasonably have resulted in, a significant release of ammonia. The purpose is to gain information that could

prevent further accidents and to identify weaknesses in the emergency response plan that need to be addressed. Investigations are initiated promptly using a trained team. The findings and recommendations will be studied and appropriate corrective action taken.

Employee Participation
The Employee Participation Program is an asset to both employees at the site and to the community as a whole.  As a general rule, employees who are fully involved have a greater sense of responsibility; they are more likely to catch the problems that can cause accidents. Employee awareness is for employees, not directly involved with the process, this includes knowing the hazards, the safety rules, warning signs, and evacuation procedures. All employees have access to the RMP/PSM Program. Involved employees participate directly in every phase of the program, including conducting the PHA, developing or reviewing operating procedures, reviewing incident investigations, and conducting mechanical integrity and compliance audits.

Community involvement is through coordination and cooperation with the local Fire department and the LEPC.

Hot Work and Safe Work Practices
This permit process is to protect against fire, explosion and other dangers resulting from hot work (welding and cutting outside the designated areas).  Hot work permits must be obtained before any work is done. The management reviews and issues the permits to insure all fire prevention and protection rules are met. Permits indicate the appropriate dates and the work to be done. The permits are kept on file until workers have completed the hot work operations.

Contractors and Contractor Qualifications
This site follows strict guidelines for qualifying contractors who directly influence the safety of the process.  The contractor qualification procedure ensures that contractors and their employees are fully aware of the potential dangers involved with the SCR process, that contractors understand their responsibility

and train their people, and that a contractor's safety record is considered in reviewing the bids. 


(d) FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There were no reportable ammonia releases at this facility during the last 5 years that meet the standard of State or Federal regulations. 

(e) EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

This facility has trained personnel to implement the Emergency Response Plan developed for this facility for flammables, fire, earthquake, hazardous materials and other emergencies. 

Facility personnel have coordinated with responding outside agencies such as the Morrow County LEPC and the local Fire Department. The facilities emergency response plan has been coordinated with the community plan which includes these agencies. 

The facility has coordinated with outside parties through drills and tabletop exercises.  Facility personnel have exchanged data with local environmental authorities, fire and contractors who might assist during an emergency.  In addition, Fire Department personnel have toured the facility on several occasions to get a better understanding of the processes and the facility during an emergency such as fire, earthquake and/or a chemical release.

Plans have been developed to assist responding personnel.  All areas (zones) can reasonably be brought under control within 20 minutes of an ammonia emergency if personnel are on site.  Small releases can be brought under control immediately.  

The emergency release response plan for all releases is to gain access to the shutdown valves and switches.  If the system shut down areas are within the ammonia release area, the SCR process may be shut down if appropriate at the DCS control computer.  

Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) technicians are trained in the use of Self Contained Breathing Apparatus and ammonia specific, stationary and portable air monitoring equipment, decontamination, clean up and disposal.

The Federal Regulations considered while developin

g this program include:
	EPA's Risk Management Plan
	OSHA's Emergency Action and Response Plan
	OSHA's Process Safety Standard
	EPA's Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know

PGE SAFETY AND HEALTH PROGRAM
This facility provides a safe and healthy workplace to their employees. As part of this commitment, Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) has an effective written Safety and Health Program. 
The written plan that covers the following elements:
 	Management commitment/assignment of responsibilities 
 	Safety communications system with employees 
 	System for assuring employee compliance with safe work practices 
 	Scheduled inspections/evaluation system 
 	Accident investigation 
 	Procedures for correcting unsafe/unhealthy conditions 
 	Safety and health training and instruction 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:
(f) PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Portland General Electric (Carty Generation Station) is proactive in their approach to health and safety of its employees and surrounding community. Any areas of improvement that can be identified in audits, hazard analyses and inspections are identified, and corrective actions are taken in the event a recommendation is made promptly.
